section.title: Present Perfect (I, you, we, they) with been
section.sectiontitle: For I, you, we and they form the Present Perfect with have + past participle, e.g. been. We usually use the contracted form 've.
section.sectiontitle2: In formal writing, use the full form.
section.text4a: They have been to my house.

section.title: Present Perfect (I, you, we, they) with been
section.sectiontitle: Make questions with have + I/we/you/they (+ ever) + past participle.
section.text2a: Have they ever been to a classical concert?
section.sectiontitle2: Make negatives with haven't (have not) + past participle or have + never + past participle.
section.text3: We've been on a long haul flight.
section.text3a: We haven't been on a long haul flight.
section.text4a: You've never been to Asia

section.title: Present Perfect (I, you, we, they) with been
section.sectiontitle: Don't repeat the past participle in short answers.
section.text1: Have you ever been to Italy?
section.text2: Have you ever been horse riding?
section.sectiontitle2: We often use the Present Perfect with ever / never to talk about experiences at any time up to now.
section.text3a: Have you ever been to Rome?
section.text4a: No, I've never been to Italy.

section.title: Present Perfect (I, you, we, they) with been
section.sectiontitle: When we use the Present Perfect, we don't say a definite time. Use the Past simple to talk about a definite time in the past.
section.text1: Have you ever been to Bangkok?
section.text1a: No, we've never been there.
section.text2: Have you ever been to Bangkok?
section.text2a: Yes, we went there last year.
